When I came home, I took two servants with me
And fetched the gentleman, hither I brought him,
And with such cheer as then the house afforded,
Replenished him, he was much mended suddenly,
Is now asleep, and when he wakes I hope
will find his senses perfect.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You did show
In this, what never was a stranger to you,
Much piety; but wander from your subject;
You have not yet discovered, who it is
Deserves your love.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Fie, fie, how dull thou art,
Thou dost not use in other things to be so;
Why I love him; his name I cannot tell thee;
For 'tis my great unhappiness to be
Still ignorant of that myself. He comes,
Look, this is he, but do not grow my rival if thou canst those.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You need not, fear't forsooth. Enter Aphron.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Leave me alone with him; withdraw.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I do. Exit maid.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Where am I now? under the Northern pole
Where a perpetual winter binds the ground
And glazeth up the floods? or where the sun
With neighbouring rays bakes the divided earth,
And drinks the rivers up? or do I sleep?
Is't not some foolish dream deludes my fancy?
Who am i? I begin to question that.
Was not my country Sicily? my name
Called Aphron, wretched Aphron?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye good gods
Forbid; is this that man who was the cause
Of all the grief for Callidora's loss?
Is this the man that I so oft have cursed?
Now I could almost hate him, and methinks
He is not quite so handsome as he was;
And yet alas he is, though by his means
My brother is gone from me, and heaven knows
If I shall see him more, fool as I am,
I cannot choose but love him.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Cheat me not good eyes,
What woman, or what angel do I see?
O stay, and let me worship ere thou goest,
Whether thou beest a goddess which thy beauty
Commands me to believe, or else some mortal
Which I the rather am induced to think,
Because I know the gods all hate me so,
They would not look upon me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Spare these titles
I am a wretched woman, who for pity
(Alas that I should pity! t'had been better(Aside)
That I had been remorseless) brought you hither,
Where with some food and rest, thanks to the gods
Your senses are recovered.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: My good angel!
I do remember now that I was mad
For want of meat and sleep, thrice did the sun
Cheer all the world but me, thrice did the night
With silent and bewitching darkness give
A resting time to every thing but Aphron.
The fish, the beasts, the birds, the smallest creatures
And the most despicable snored securely.
The aguish head of every tree by Aeolus
Was rocked asleep, and shook as if it nodded.
The crooked mountains seemed to bow and slumber,
The very rivers ceased their daily murmur,
Nothing did watch, but the pale moon, and I
Paler than she; grief wedded to this toil
What else could it beget but franticness?
But now methinks , I am my own, my brain
Swims not as it was wont; oh brightest virgin
Show me some way by which I may be grateful,
And if I do't not, let an eternal frenzy
Immediately seize on me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Alas! 'twas only
My love, and if you will reward me for't,
Pay that i lent you, I'll require no interest;
The principal's enough.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: You speak in mists.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You're loath perhaps to understand.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: If you intend that I should love and honour you,
I do by all the gods.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: But I am covetous in my demands,
I am not satisfied with windlike promises
Which only touch the lips; I ask your heart
Your whole heart for me, in exchange of mine,
Which so I gave to you.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Ha! you amaze me.
Oh! you have spoken something worse than lightning,
That blasts the inward parts, leaves, the outward whole,
My gratitude commands me to obey you,
But I am born a man, and have those passions
Fighting within me, which I must obey.
Whilst Callidora lives, although she be
As cruel, as thy breast is soft and gentle;
'Tis sin for me to think of any other.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You cannot love me then?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: I do I swear,
Above myself I do: myself? what said I?
Alas! that's nothing; above any thing
But heaven and Callidora.

sp.speaker: Cl ▪
sp.l: Fare you well then,
I would not do that wrong to one I love,
To urge him farther than his power and will;
Farewell, remember me when you are gone,
And happy in the love of Callidora. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: When i do not, may I forget myself,
Would I were mad again; then I might rave
With privilege, I should not know the griefs
That hurried me about, 'twere better far
To lose the senses, then be tortured by them.
Where is she gone? I did not ask her name,
Fool that I was, alas poor gentlewoman!
Can any one love me? ye cruel gods,
is't not enough that I myself am miserable,
Must I make others so too? I'll go in
And comfort her; alas! how can I though?
I'll grieve with her, that is in ills a comfort.

div.stage: Enter Alupis, Melarnus, Truga, Palaemon, Aegon.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Before when you denied your daughter to me
'Twas fortune's fault, not mine, but since good fate
Or rather Aegon, better far than fate
Hath raised me up to what you aimed at, riches,
I see not with what countenance you can
Coin any second argument against me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come, no matter for that:
Yes, I could wish you were less eloquent,
You have a vice called poesy which much
Displeaseth me, but no matter for that neither.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Alas! he'll leave that straight
When he has got but money; he that swims
In Tagus, never will go back to Helicon.
Besides, when he hath married Hylace
Whom should he woo, to praise her comely feature,
Her skin like falling snow, her eyes like stars,
Her cheeks like roses (Which are common places
Of all your lovers praises) ôh! those vanities,
Things quite as light, and foolish as a mistress,
Are by a mistress first begot, and left
When they leave her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why do you think that poesy
An art which even the gods —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pox on your arts,
Let him think what he will; what's that to us?

sp.speaker: Aegon.
sp.l: Well, I would gladly have an answer of you,
Since I have made Palaemon here my son,
If you conceive your daughter is so good,
We will not press you, but seek out some other
who may perhaps please me and him as well.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Which is impossible '—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Rot on your possibles —
Thy mouth like a cracked fiddle never sounds
But out of tune; come, put on Truga
You'll never speak unless I show the ring.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I do, I do; do ye hear sweet heart?
Are you mad to fling away a fortune
That's thrust upon you, you know aegon's rich.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come, no matter for that,
That's thrust upon me? I would fain see any man
Thrust ought upon me; but's no matter for that,
I will do that which I intend to do,
And 'tis no matter for that neither, that's thrust upon me?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Come, what say you Melarnus?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What say I? 'tis no matter what I say,
I'll speak to Aegon, if I speak to any,
And not to you; but no matter for that;
Hark you, will you leave all the means you have
To this Palaemon?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I duck, he says he will.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pish, 'tis no matter for that, I'll hear him say so.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I will, and here do openly protest,
That since my Bellula (Mine that was once)
Thinks herself wiser than her father is,
And will be governed rather by her passions,
Then by the square that I prescribe to her,
That I will never count her as my daughter.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Well acted by God pan, see but what 'tis
To have me for a tutor in these rogueries.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But tell me now, good neighbour, what estate
Do you intend to give him?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: That estate
Which fortune and my care hath given to me,
The money which I have, and that's not much,
The sheep, and goats.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And not the oxen too?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Yes; every thing.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The horses too?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I tell you, every thing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By pan he'll make him promise him particularly
Each thing above the value of a beans-straw.
You'll leave him the pails too, to milk the kine in,
And harness for the horses, will you not?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ay, ay, what else; but 'tis no matter for that,
I know palaemon's an ingenious man,
And love him therefore; but's no matter for that neither

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Well, since we are both agreed, why do we stay here
I know Palaemon longs t'embrace his Hylace.

sp.speaker: Mel ▪
sp.l: Ay, ay, 'tis no matter for that, within this hour
We will be ready, Aegon, pray be you so,
Farewell my son in law that shall be,
But's no matter for that: farewell all:
Come Truga. Exeunt Melarnus and Truga.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Come on then, let's not stay too long in trifling,
Palaemon go, and prepare yourself against the time.
I'll go acquaint my Bellula with your plot,
Lest this unwelcome news should too much grieve her,
Before she know my meaning.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Do, do; and I'll go study
Some new-found ways to vex the fool Malernus.
For 'tis but a folly,
To be melancholy, etc.
Whilst Callidorus lives, I cannot love thee.
These were her parting words; I'll kill him then;
Why do I doubt it fool? such wounds as these
Require no gentler medicine; methinks love
Frowns at me now, and says I am too dull,
Too slow in his command: and yet I will not,
these hands are virgins yet, unstained with villainy,
Shall I begin to teach them? — methinks piety
Frowns at me now, and says, I am too weak
Against my passions. Piety! —
'T was fear begotten that bugbear; for thee Bellula
I durst be wicked, though I saw Jove's hand
Armed with a naked thunderbolt: farewell,
If thou beest any thing, and not a shadow
To fright boys and old women) farewell conscience,
Go and be strong in other petty things
To lovers come, when lovers may make use of thee,
Not else: and yet, — what shall I do or say?
I see the better way, and know 'tis better,
Yet still this devious error draws me backward.
So when contrary winds rush out and meet,
And wrestle on the sea with equal fury
The waves swell into mountains, and are driven
Now back, now forward, doubtful of the two
Which captain to obey.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I'll have such excellent sport
For 'tis but a folly, etc.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why here's a fellow now makes sport of every thing,
See one man's fate how it excels another,
He can sit, and pass away the day in jollity,
My music is my sighs, whilst tears keep time.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Who's here? A most rare posture!
How the good soul folds in his arms! he dreams
Sure that he hugs his mistress now, for that
Is his disease without all doubt, so, good,
With what judicious garb he plucks his hat
Over his eyes; so, so, good! better yet;
He cries; by this good light, he cries; the man
Is careful, and intends to water his sheep
with his own tears; ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Dost thou see any thing that deserves thy laughter,
Fond swain?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I see nothing in good troth but you,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: To jeer those who are fates may-game
Is a redoubled fault; for 'tis both sin,
And folly too; our life is so uncertain
Thou canst not promise that thy mirth shall last
Tomorrow, and not meet with any rub,
Than thou mayst act that part, today thou laughest as

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I act a part? it must be in a comedy then,
I abhor tragedies: besides, I never
Practised this posture; heigh ho! woe, alas!
Why do I live? my music is my sighs
Whilst tears keep time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You take too great a licence to your wit;
Wit, did I say? I mean, that which you think so.
And it deserves my pity, more than anger.
Else you should find, that blows are heavier far
Than the most studied jests you can throw at me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith it will be but labour lost to beat me,
All will not teach me how to act this part;
Woe's me! alas! I'm a dull rogue, and so
Shall never learn it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You're unmannerly
To talk thus saucily with one you know not,
Nay, hardly ever saw before, be gone
And leave me as you found me, my worst thoughts
Are better company than thou.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Enjoy them then,
Here's nobody desires to rob you of them.
I would have left your company without bidding,
'Tis not so pleasant, I remember well,
When I had spent all my money, I stood thus
And therefore hate the posture ever since.
D'ye hear? I'm going to a wedding now;
if you've a mind to dance, come along with me,
Bring your hard-hearted mistress with you too,
Perhaps I may persuade her, and tell her
Your music's sighs, and that your tears keep time.
Will you not go? Farewell then, good tragical actor.
Now have at thee Melarnus; for 'tis but a folly, etc. Exit

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou art a prophet, shepherd; she is hard
As rocks which suffer the continual siege
Of sea and wind against them; but I will
Win her or lose (Which I should gladly do)
Myself: myself? why so I have already:
Ho! who hath found Florellus? he is lost,
Lost to himself, and to his parents likewise,
(Who having missed me, do by this time search
Each corner for to find me) ôh! Florellus,
Thou must be wicked, or for ever wretched,
Hard is the physic, harder the disease.

div.head: Actus v.
Scaena i.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The gods convert these omens into good:
And mock my fears; thrice in the very threshold,
Without its masters leave my foot stood still,
Thrice in the way it stumbled:

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thrice, and thrice
You were a fool then for observing it.
Why these are follies the young years of Truga
Did hardly know; are they not vanished yet?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Blame not my fear: that's Cupid's usher always;
Though Hylace were now in my embraces,
I should half doubt it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If you chanced to stumble.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Let him enjoy his madness, the same liberty
He'll grant to you, when you're a lover too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ay, when I am, he may; yet if I were one
I should not be dismayed because threshold —

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Alas! that was not all, as I came by
The oak to Faunus sacred, where the shepherd's
Exercise rural sports on festivals,
On that trees top an inauspicious crow
Foretold some ill to happen.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: And because crows
Foretell wet weather, you interpret it
The rain of your own eyes; but leave these tricks
and let me advise you.

div.stage: Melarnus speaking to Hylace within his door.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Well come, no matter for that; I do believe thee; girl
And would they have such sport with vexing me!
But's no matter for that; I'll vex them for't.
I know your fiery lover will be here straight,
But I shall cool him; but come, no matter for that!
Go get you in, for I do see them coming.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Here comes Melarnus.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: He looks cheerfully, I hope all's well?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Melarnus, opportunely: we were a coming
Just now unto you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yes, very likely; would you have spoken with me?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Spoken with you?
Why, are you mad? have you forgotten your promise?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My promise? o! 'tis true, I said indeed
I would go with you today to sell some kine,
Stay but a little, I'll be ready straight.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am amazed; good Aegon speak to him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By this good light,
I see no likelihood of any marriage,
Except betwixt the kine and oxen. Hark you hither;
A rotten upon your beasts; is Hylace ready?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: It's no matter for that! who's there? Alupis?
Give me thy hand i'faith, thou'rt a merry fellow,
I have not seen thee here these many days,
But now I think on't, it's no matter for that neither.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thy memory's fled away sure with thy wit.
Was not I here less than an hour ago
With Aegon, when you made the match?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Oh! then you'll go along with us,
Faith do; for you will make us very merry.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I shall, if you thus make a fool of me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: O no! you'll make you sport with vexing me,
but mum; no matter for that neither: there
I bobbed him privately, I think. Aside.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Come, what's the business?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The business? why he's mad, beyond the cure
Of all the herbs grow in Anticyra.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: You see we have not failed our word Melarnus,
I and my son are come.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Your son! goodlack!
I thought, I swear, you had no other child
Besides your daughter Bellula.

sp.speaker: Aegon.
sp.l: Nay, than
I see you are disposed to make us fools, —
Did not I tell you that 'twas my intent
To adopt Palaemon for my son and heir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Did not you examine
Whether he would leave him all, lest that he should
Adopt some other heir to the cheese-presses,
The milking-pails, and cream-bowls? did you not?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: In troth 'tis well; but where is Bellula?

sp.speaker: Aegon.
sp.l: Nay; prithee leave these tricks, and tell me
What you intend, is Hylace ready?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ready? what else? she's to be married presently:
To a young shepherd, but's no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: That's I, hence fears;
Attend upon the infancy of love,
She's now mine own.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why I; did not the crow on the oak foretell you this?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Hylace, Hylace, come forth,
Here's some are come to dance at your wedding,
And they're welcome. (Enter Hylace.)

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The light appears, just like the rising sun,
When o'er yond hill it peeps, and with a draught
Of morning dew salutes the day, how fast
The night of all my sorrow flies away,
Quite banished with her sight!

sp.speaker: Hy.
sp.l: Did you call for me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Is Damaetas come? Fie, how slow he is
At such a time? but it's no matter for that;
Well get you in, and prepare to welcome him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Will you be gone so quickly, ôh! bright Hylace
That blessed hour by me so often begged,
By you so oft denied, is now approaching.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What, how now? what do you kiss her? (Exit Hylace.)
If Damoetas were here, he would grow jealous,
But 'tis a parting kiss, and so in manners
She cannot deny it you; but it's no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What do you wonder at?
Why do you think as soon as they are married,
Damoetas such a fool, to let his wife
Be kissed by everybody ?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How now? Damoetas?
Why what hath he to do with her?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ha, ha!
What hath the husband then to do with's wife?
Good: 'tis no matter for that though; he knows what.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: You mean Palaemon sure, ha, do you not?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter for that, what I mean, I mean,
Well, rest ye merry gentlemen, I must in,
And see my daughter's wedding, if you please
To dance with us; Damaetas sure will thank ye;
Pray bring your son and heir Palaemon with you,
Bellula's cast away, ha, ha, ha, ha!
And the poor fool Melarnus must be cheated,
But it's no matter for that; how now Alupis?
I thought you would have had most excellent sport
With abusing poor Melarnus? that same coxcomb,
For he's a fool; but it's no matter for that,
Aegon hath cheated him, Palaemon is
Married to Hylace, and one Alupis
Doth nothing else but vex him, ha, ha, ha!
But it's no matter for that; farewell gentles,
or if you'll come and dance, ye shall be welcome,
Will you Palaemon? 'tis your mistress wedding.
I am a fool, a coxcomb, gulled on every side,
No matter for that though; what I have done, I have done ▪
Ha, ha, ha! Exit.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: How now? what are you both dumb? both thunderstruck?
This was your plot Alupis.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'll begin.
May his sheep rotten, and he for want of food
Be forced to eat them then; may every man
Abuse him, and yet he not have the wit
To abuse any man, may he never speak
More sense than he did now; and may he never
Be rid of his old wife Truga, may his son
In law be a more famous cuckold made
Then any one I knew when I lived in the city.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Fool as thou art, the sun shall lose his course ▪
And brightness too, ere Hylace her chastity.
O no! ye gods, may she be happy always,
Happy in the embraces of Damoetas;
And that shall be some comfort to my ghost
When I am dead; and dead I shall be shortly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: May a disease seize upon all his cattle,
And a far worse on him; till he at last
Be carried to some hospital i'the city,
And there killed by a chirurgeon for experience.
And when he's gone, I'll wish this good thing for him,
May the earth lie gently on him — that the dogs
May tear him up the easier.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: A curse upon thee!
And upon me for trusting thy fond counsels!
Was this your cunning trick? why thou hast wounded
My conscience and my reputation too,
With what face can I look on the other swains?
Or who will ever trust me, who have broke
My faith thus openly?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: A curse upon thee,
This is the second time that thy persuasions
Made me not only fool, but wicked too;
I should have died in quiet else, and known
No other wound, but that of her denial;
Go now, and brag how thou hast used Palaemon,
But yet methinks you might have chose some other
For subject of your mirth, not me.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And yet if this had prospered (As I wonder
Who it should be, betrayed us, since we three
And Truga only knew it, whom, if she
Betrayed us, I —) if this, I say, had prospered,
You would have hugged me for inventing it,
And him for putting it in act; foolish men
That do not mark the thing but the event!
Your judgements hang on fortune, not on reason ▪

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Dost thou upbraid us too?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: First make us wretched,
And then laugh at us? believe, Alupis,
Thou shalt not long have cause to boast thy villainy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My villainy? do what ye can: you're fools,
And there's an end; I'll talk with you no more,
I had as good speak reason to the wind
As you, that can but hiss at it.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: We will do more; Palaemon, come away ▪
He hath wronged both; and both shall satisfy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Which he will never do; nay, go and plod,
Your two wise brains will invent certainly
Politic begins to catch me in. Exeunt.
And now have at thee Truga, if I find
That thou art guilty; mum, — I have a ring. —
Palaemon, Aegon, Hylace, Melarnus
Are all against me; no great matter: hang care,
For 'tis but a folly, etc.
This way my Callidorus went, what chance
Hath snatched him from my sight? how shall I find him?
How shall I find myself, now I have lost him?
With ye my feet and eyes I will not make
The smallest truce, till ye have sought him out.
Come, now your business.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a fatal one,
Which will almost as much shame me to speak,
Much more to act, as 'twill fright you to hear it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fright me? it must be then some wickedness,
I am accustomed so to misery,
That cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Oh! 'tis a sin young man,
A sin which every one shall wonder at,
None not condemn, if ever it be known?
Methinks my blood shrinks back into my veins,
And my affrighted hairs are turned to bristles.
Do not my eyes creep back into their cells ▪
As if they seemed to wish for thicker darkness,
Than either night or death to cover them?
Doth not my face look black and horrid too?
As black and horrid as my thoughts? ha! tell me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am a novice in all villainies,
If your intents be such, dismiss me, pray,
My nature is more easy to discover
Then help you; so, farewell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yet stay a little longer; you must stay ▪
You are an actor in this tragedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What would you do?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas! I would do nothing; but I must —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What must you do?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I must. — love thou hast got the victory —
Kill thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who? me? you do but jest,
I should believe you, if I could tell how
To frame a cause, or think on any injury
Worth such a large revenge, which I have done you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O no! there's all the wickedness, they may seem
To find excuse for their abhorred fact;
That kill when wrongs, and anger urgeth them;
Because thou art so good, so affable.
So full of graces, both of mind and body,
Therefore I kill thee, wilt thou know it plainly,
Because whilst thou art living, Bellula
Protested she would never be another's,
Therefore I kill thee.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Had I been your rival
You might have had some cause; cause did I say?
You might have had pretence for such a villainy:
He who unjustly kills is twice a murderer.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He whom love bids to kill is not a murderer.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Call not that love that's ill; 'tis only fury.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fury in ills is half excusable:
Therefore prepare thyself; if any sin
(Though I believe thy hot and flourishing youth,
As innocent as other men's nativities)
Hath flung a spot upon thy purer conscience
Wash it in some few tears.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Are you resolved to be so cruel?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I must, or be as cruel to myself.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: As sick men do their beds, so have I yet
Enjoyed myself, with little rest, much trouble:
I have been made the ball of love and fortune,
And am almost worn out with often playing.
And therefore I would entertain my death
As some good friend whose coming I expected;
Were it not that my parents —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Here; see, I do not come(Draws two swords from under his garment and offers one to call.)
Like a foul murderer to entrap you falsely,
Take your own choice, and then defend yourself.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly done; and since it must be so,
Although my strength and courage call me woman
I will not die like sheep without resistance,
If innocence be guard sufficient,
I'm sure he cannot hurt me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Are you ready? the fatal cuckoo on yond spreading tree
Hath sounded out your dying knell already.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and I could wish thy hand
Were strong enough; 'tis thou deservest the victory,
Nay, were not th'hope of Bellula engraven
In all my thoughts, I would myself play booty
Against myself; but Bellula — come on. Fight
This is the wood adjoining to the farm,
Where I gave order unto Clariana
My sister, to remain till my return;
Here 'tis in vain to seek her, yet who knows?
Though it be in vain I'll seek; to him that doth
Propose no journey's end, no paths amiss.
Why how now? what do you mean? for shame part shepherds,
I thought you honest shepherds, had not hadSees them fighting.
So much of court, and city follies in you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis Philistus; I hope he will not know me,
Now I begin to see how black and horrid
My attempt was; how much unlike Florellus,
Thanks to the juster deities for declining
From both the danger, and from me the sin.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Twould be a wrong to charity to dismiss ye
Before I see you friends, give me your weapons.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis he; why do I doubt? most willingly,
and myself too, best man; now kill me shepherd —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What do you mean? ('swounds)
Rise, prithee rise; sure you have wounded him.
Deceive me not good eyes; what do I see?
My Callidorus dead? 'tis impossible!
Who is it that lies slain there? are you dumb?
Who is't I pray?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fair mistress —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pish, fair mistress, —
I ask who 'tis; if it be Callidorus —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was his name Callidorus? it is strange.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are a villain, and you too a villain,
Wake Callidorus, wake, it is thy Bellula
That calls thee, wake, it is thy Bellula;
Why gentlemen? why shepherd? fie for shame,
Have you no charity? O my Callidorus!
Speak but one word —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis not well done to trouble me,
Why do you envy me this little rest?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No; I will follow thee. ('swounds.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O help, help quickly,
What do you mean? your Callidorus lives.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Callidorus!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And will be well immediately, take courage,
Look up a little: wretched as I am,
I am the cause of all this ill.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What shall we do? I have a sister dwells
Close by this place, let's haste to bring them thither.
But let's be sudden.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As winged lightning is.
Come Bellula in spite of fortune now
I do embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I did protest without my Callidora
Never to return, but pity hath o'ercome.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Where I could always wish thee: in those arms
Which would enfold thee with more subtle knots,
Then amorous ivy, whilst it hugs the oak.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where do ye bear me? is Philistus well?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How should he know my name? 'tis to me a riddle
Nay shepherd find another time to court in,
Make haste now with your burden.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With what ease should I go always were I burdened thus!Exeunt
She told me she was sister to Philistus ▪
Who having missed the beauteous Callidora,
Hath undertook a long, and hopeless journey
To find her out; then Callidora's fled,
Without her parent's knowledge, and who knows
When she'll return, or if she do, what then?
Lamb's will make peace, and join themselves with wolves
Ere she with me, worse than a wolf to her:
Besides, how durst I undertake to court her?
How dare I look upon her after this?
Fool as I am, I will forget her quite,
And Clariana shall henceforth — but yet
How fair she was! what then? so's Clariana ▪
What graces did she dart on all beholders?
She did; but so does Clariana too,
She was as pure and white as Parian marble,
What then? She was as hard too; Clariana
Is pure and white as Ericina's doves,
And is as soft, as gall-less too as they,
Her pity saved my life, and did restore
My wand'ring senses, if I should not love her,
I were far madder now, then when she found me,
I will go in and render up myself,
For her most faithful servant.
Wonderful! Exit. Enter again.
She has locked me in, and keeps me here her prisoner.
In these two chambers; what can she intend?
No matter, she intends no hurt I'm sure,
I'll patiently expect her coming to me. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Demophil, Spodaia, Clariana, Florellus, Callidora, Bellula, Philistus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My daughter found again, and son returned!
Ha, ha! methinks it makes me young again.
My daughter and my son meet here together!
Philistus with them too! that we should come
To grieve with Clariana, and find her here.
Nay, when we thought we had lost Florellus too
To find them both, methinks it makes me young again.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.l: I thought I never should have seen thee more
My Callidora; come wench, now let's hear,
The story of your flight and life in the woods.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Do happy mistress for the recordation,
Of fore past ills, makes us the sweetlier relish
Our present good.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Of Aphron's love to me, and my antipathy
Towards him, there's none here ignorant, you know too.
How guarded with his love, or rather fury,
And some few men he broke into our house
With resolution to make me the prey
Of his wild lust.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Ay, there's a villain now; o! that I had him here.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh! say not so:
The crimes which lovers for their mistress act
Bear both the weight and stamp of piety.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come girl; go on, go on. His wild lust —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What sudden fear shook me, you may imagine,
What should I do? you both were out of town,
And most of the servants at that time gone with you.
I on the sudden found a corner out,
And hid myself, till they wearied with searching,
quit the house, but fearing lest they should
Attempt the same again ere your return,
I took with me money and other necessaries;
And in a suit my brother left behind
Disguised myself, thus to the woods I went,
Where meeting with an honest merry swain,
I by his help was furnished, and made shepherd.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Nay, I must needs say for her, she was always
A witty wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pish, pish: and made a shepherd —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It happened that this gentle shepherdess,
(I can attribute it to naught in me
Deserved so much) began to love me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why so did all besides I'll warrant you,
Nor can I blame them, though they were my rival.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Another shepherd with as much desire
Wooed her in vain, as she in vain wooed me,
Who seeing that no hope was left for him,
Whilst I enjoyed this life t'enjoy his Bellula,
(For by that name she's known) sought to take me
Out of the way as a partition
Betwixt his love and him, whilst in the fields
We two were struggling, (Him his strength defending.
And me my innocence.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am ashamed to look upon their faces.
What shall I say? my guilt's above excuse.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Philistus; as if the gods had all agreed
To make him mine, just at the nick came in
And parted us, with sudden joy I sounded,
Which Bellula perceiving (For even then
She came to seek me) sudden grief did force
The same effect from her, which joy from me.
Hither they brought us both, in this amazement,
Where being straight recovered to ourselves,
I found you here, and you your dutiful daughter.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.l: The gods be thanked.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Go on.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, you have all sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Where's that shepherd?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, where?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Here, your unhappy son's the man; for her
I put on sylvan weeds, for her fair sake
I would have stained my innocent hands in blood,
Forgive me all, 'twas not a sin of malice,
'Twas not begotten by lust, but sacred love;
The cause must be the excuse for the effect.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You should have used some other means, Florellus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas! 'twas the god's will sir, without that
I had been undiscovered yet; Philistus
Wandered too far, my brother yet a shepherd,
You groaning for our loss, upon this wheel
All our felicity is turned.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Alas! you have forgotten the power of love, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Be patient son, and temper your desire,
You shall not want a wife that will perhaps
Please you as well, I'm sure befit you better.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They marry not, but sell themselves t'a wife,
Whom the large dowry tempts, and take more pleasure
To hug the wealthy bags than her that brought them.
Let them whom nature bestows nothing on
Seek to patch up their want by parents' plenty;
The beautiful, the chaste, the virtuous,
Herself alone is portion to herself.
By your leave; I come to seek a daughter.
O! are you there, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This is her father,
I do conjure you father, by the love
Which parents bear their children, to make up
The match betwixt us now, or if you will not
Send for your friends, prepare a coffin for me
And let a grave be digged, I will be happy,
or else not know my misery tomorrow;

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.l: You do not think what ill may happen husband,
Come, let him have her, you have means enough
For him, the wench is fair, and if her face
Be not a flatterer, of a noble mind,
Although not stock.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I do not like this straggling, come along,
By your leave gentlemen, I hope you will
Pardon my bold intrusion.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You're very welcome.
What are you going Bellula? pray stay,
Though nature contradicts our love, I hope
That I may have your friendship.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Bellula!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My father calls; farewell; your name, and memory
In spite of fate, I'll love, farewell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Would you be gone, and not bestow one word
Upon your faithful servant? do not all
My griefs and troubles for your sake sustained.
Deserve, farewell Florellus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fare you well then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas! how can I, sweet, unless you stay,
Or I go with you? you were pleased ere while
To say you honoured me with the next place
To Callidorus in your heart, then now
I should be first: do you repent your sentence?
Or can that tongue sound less than oracle?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Perhaps I am of that opinion still,
But must obey my father.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Why Bellula? would you have ought with her sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, I would have herself; if constancy
And love be meritorious, I deserve her.
Why father, mother, sister, gentlemen,
Will you plead for me?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Since't must be so, I'll bear it patiently,
Shepherd you see how much our son is taken
With your fair daughter, therefore if you think
him fitting for her husband speak, and let it
Be made a match immediately, we shall
Expect no other dowry than her virtue.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Which only I can promise; for her fortune
Is beneath you so far, that I could almost
Suspect your words, but that you seem more noble.
How now, what say you girl?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I only do depend upon your will.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: And I'll not be an enemy to thy good fortune.
Take her sir, and the gods bless you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With greater joy than I would take a crown.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The gods bless you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They have don't already.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Lest you should think when time, and oft enjoying
Hath dulled the point, and edge of your affection
That you have wronged yourself and family,
By marrying one whose very name, a shepherdess,
Might fling some spot upon your birth, I'll tell you,
She is not mine, nor born in these rude woods:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How! you speak misty wonders.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I speak truth's sir,
Some fifteen years ago, as I was walking
I found a nurse wounded, and groaning out
Her latest spirit, and by her a fair child ▪
And, which her very dressing might declare,
Of wealthy parents, as soon as I came to them
I asked her who had used her so inhumanly:
She answered Turkish pirates; and withal
Desired me to look unto the child,
For 'tis, said she, a nobleman's of Sicily,
His name she would have spoke, but death permitted not.
Her as I could, I caused to be buried,
But brought home the little girl with me,
Where by my wife's persuasions we agreed,
Because the gods had blessed us with no issue,
To nourish as our own, and call it Bellula
whom now you see, your wife, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Her manners showed her noble.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I call the gods to witness, this is true.
And for the farther testimony of it,
I have yet kept at home the furniture,
And the rich mantle which she then was wrapped in,
Which now perhaps may serve to some good use
Thereby to know her parents.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sure this is Aphron's sister then, for just
About the time he mentions, I remember,
The governor of Pachinus, than his father
Told me that certain pirates of Argier
Had broke into his house, and stolen from thence
With other things his daughter, and her nurse,
Who being after taken, and executed,
Their last confession was, that they indeed
Wounded the nurse, but she fled with the child,
Whilst they were busy searching for more prey.
Whom since her father, neither saw, nor heard of.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then now I'm sure sir, you would gladly pardon
The rash attempt of Aphron, for your daughter,
Since fortune hath joined, both of you by kindred.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Most willingly:

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.l: Ay, ay, alas! 'twas love:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Where should we find him out?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll save that labour. Exit Clariana.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where's Hylace pray shepherd? and the rest
Of my good sylvan friends? methinks I would,
Fain take my leave of them.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: I'll fetch them hither.
They're not far off, and if you please to help
The match betwixt Hylace and Palaemon,
'Twould be a good deed, I'll go fetch them.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Ha! whither have you led me Clariana?
Some steepy mountain bury me alive,
or rock entomb me in its stony entrails,
Whom do I see?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do you stare my Aphron?
They have forgiven all.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come, Aphron, welcome,
We have forgotten the wrong you did my daughter,
The name of love hath covered all; this is
A joyful day, and sacred to great Hymen
'Twere sin not to be friends with all men now.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Methinks, I have much ado to forgive the rascal. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: I know not what to say; do you all pardon me?
I have done wrong to ye all, yea, to all those
That have a share in virtue. Can ye pardon me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Do you say so fair virgin?
You I have injured most: with love,
With saucy love, which I henceforth recall,
And will look on you with an adoration,
Not with desire hereafter; tell me, pray,
Doth any man yet call you his?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes; Philistus.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: I congratulate it sir.
The gods make ye both happy: fool, as I am,
You are at the height already of felicity,
To which there's nothing can be added now,
But perpetuity; you shall not find me
Your rival any more, though I confess
I honour her, and will for ever do so.
Clariana, I am so much unworthy
Of thy love. That —

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Go no farther sir, 'tis I should say so
Of my own self.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How sister? are you two so near upon a match?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: In our heart's sir,
We are already joined, it may be though
You will be loath to have unhappy Aphron,
style you his brother?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No sir, if you both
Agree, to me it shall not be unwelcome.
Why here's a day indeed; sure Hymen now
Means to spend all his torches.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis my son sir,
New come from travail, and your brother now.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: I understand not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Had you not a sister?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: I had sir; but where now she is none knows,
Besides the gods.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is't not about some fifteen years ago
Since that the nurse 'scaped with her from the hands
Of Turkish pirates that beset the house?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: It is sir.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: Your sister lives then, and is married
Now to Florellus; this is she, you shall be
Informed of all the circumstances anon.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible.
I shall be made too happy on the sudden.
My sister found, and Clariana mine!
Come not too thick good joys, you will oppress me.

div.stage: Enter Melarnus, Truga, Aegon, Hylace, Palaemon.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Shepherds you're welcome all; though I have lost
Your good society, I hope I shall not
Your friendship, and best wishes.

sp.speaker: Aegon.
sp.l: Nay, here's wonders;
Now Callidorus is found out a woman,
Bellula not my daughter, and is married
To yonder gentleman, for which I intend
To do in earnest what before I jested,
To adopt Palaemon for my heir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!
Come it's no matter for that; do you think
To cheat me once again with your fine tricks?
No matter for that neither. Ha, ha, ha!
Alas! she's married to Dametas.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Nay, that was your plot Melarnus,
I met with him, and he denies it to me.

sp.speaker: Hy.
sp.l: Henceforth I must not love, but honour you — to Callidora ▪

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: By all the gods I will.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: He will, he will; duck.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Of everything?

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Of every thing; I call
These gentlemen to witness here, that since
I have no child to care for; I will make
Palaemon heir to those small means the gods,
Have blessed me with, if he do marry Hylace.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come it's no matter for that, I scarce believe you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We'll be his sureties.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Hylace
What think you of Palaemon? can you love him?
Has our consents, but it's no matter for that,
If he do please you, speak, or now, or never.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Why do I doubt fond girl? she's now a woman.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No matter for that, what you do, do quickly.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: My duty binds me not to be averse
To what likes you. —

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why take her then Palaemon; she's yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: With far more joy
Than I would do the wealth of both the Indyes,
Thou art above a father to me, Aegon.
We're freed from misery with sense of joy,
We are not born so; o! my Hylace,
It is my comfort now that thou wert hard,
And cruel till this day, delights are sweetest?
When poisoned with the trouble to attain them.
For 'tis but a folly, etc.
By your leave, I come to seek a woman,
that hath outlived the memory of her youth,
With skin as black as her teeth, if she have any,
With a face would fright the constable and his watch
Out of their wits (And that's easily done you'll say) if they
Should meet her at midnight.
O! are you there? I thought I smelled you somewhere;
Come hither my she Nestor, pretty Truga,
Come hither, my sweet duck.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Why? are you not ashamed to abuse me thus,
Before this company?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I have something more;
I come to show the ring before them all;
How durst you thus betray us to Melarnus?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: 'Tis false, 'twas Hylace that overheard you;
She told me so; but they are married now.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What do you think to flam me? why ho! here's news.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Alupis art thou there? forgive my anger,
I am the happiest man alive, Alupis,
Hylace is mine, here are more wonders too,
Thou shalt know all anon.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Alupis, give me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Well, rather than be troubled.

sp.speaker: Aeg.
sp.l: Alupis welcome, now we're friends I hope?
Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With all my heart,
I'm glad to see ye have learned more wit at last.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This is the shepherd, father, to whose care
I owe for many favours in the woods,
You're welcome heartily; here's everybody
Paired of a sudden; when shall's see you married?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Me? when there are no ropes to hang myself,
No rocks to break my neck down; I abhor
To live in a perpetual belfry;
I never could abide to have a master,
Much less a mistress, and I will not marry,
Because, I'll sing away the day,
For 'tis but a folly to be melancholy,
I'll be merry whilst I may.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You're welcome all, and I desire you all
To be my guests today; a wedding dinner,
Such as the sudden can afford, we'll have,
Come will ye walk in gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
What crosses have ye born before ye joined!
What seas passed through before ye touched the port!
Thus lovers do, ere they are crowned by fates
With palm, the tree their patience imitates.

div.head: Epilogue spoken by Alupis.
div.l: The author bid me tell you — i'faith, I have
Forgotten what 'twas; and I'm a very slave
If I know what to say; but only this,
Be merry, that my counsel always is.
Let no grave man knit up his brow, and say,
'Tis foolish: why? 'twas a boy made the play.
Nor any yet of those that sit behind,
Because he goes in plush, be of his mind.
Let none his time, or his spent money grieve,
Be merry; give me your hands, and I'll believe.
Or if you will not, I'll go in, and see,
If I can turn the author's mind, with me
To sing away the day,
For 'tis but a folly
To be melancholy,
Since that can't mend the play.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
